items.title: JVM shutdown failed
items.body: When I used `jpype.shutdownJVM()` in Python to shut down the JVM，After, I used `jpype.isJVMStarted()`, return `True`.

items.title: JString slice operator
items.body: I did a deep scan of the github forums.   It appears the most common problem with convert strings (other than we gave a deprecation warning for a year) is the lack of support for slicing on JString.   It isn't too much to add and will save some of those older libraries that have not yet switched to setting a conversion policy.

items.title: Improve error message for static mismatch

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Improvement in capability planned for future release

items.body:
One common error when using JPype is when a member method is called statically.  The error message that this gives is somewhat decieving.

```
class Foo{
   public bar(int i);
}
```

When called as ``Foo.bar(1)`` will give

```
TypeError: No matching overloads found for Foo.bar(int), options are:
        public Foo(int)
```

The message is correct.  You didn't call bar with a object and the only one that matches is not static.   To improve the error message I recommend we check the types of the first argument of the method and the one provided to make the output read as 

```
TypeError: No matching overloads found for *static* Foo.bar(int), options are:
        public Foo(int)
```

It can still be fooled by methods that have this and the first argument the same but it should cut down on the number of confused users a bunch.

items.title: KeyboardInterrupt not being raised after starting the JVM
items.body:
In #255 there was some code to demonstrate a problem with ``KeyboardInterrupt`` not being raised after starting the JVM & then pressing ``Ctrl+C``. This can be easily reproduced with:

```
import time

import jpype as jp


jp.startJVM(
    jp.getDefaultJVMPath(),
)

try:
    while True:
        print(".", end="", flush=True)
        time.sleep(1)
except KeyboardInterrupt as e:
    print('Interrupt requested')
    raise
finally:
    print("This should be always executed", flush=True)
```

As you can see, hitting ``ctrl+c`` while this is running does not result in the while-loop being terminated, and the execution continues indefinitely. In ``JPype1<1`` the ``KeyboardInterrupt`` is honoured (i.e. the process terminates) but it doesn't actually trigger the ``KeyboardInterrupt`` (nor the ``finally`` block).

One solution to this (from #255) is to add the ``-Xrs`` flag at JVM startup (From Java help: ``-Xrs: reduce use of OS signals by Java/VM (see documentation)``). Unfortunately this flag now triggers a ``SystemError: java.lang.RuntimeException: java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException`` if you try to start the JVM with the ``-Xrs`` flag.

Another solution is to turn on a special signal handler, such as ``signal.signal(signal.SIGINT, handler)`` where ``handler`` just ``raise KeyboardInterrupt()``. This solution works for JPype 0.6, 0.7 and 1.0, but it is not expected Python behaviour to have to enable ``KeyboardInterrupt``s in this way.

Is there something missing in JPype that needs to be done to enable this (expected) behaviour out of the box?

items.title: Feature request optimize numpy array transfer

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Improvement in capability planned for future release

items.body:
The benchmarking of transfer of large arrays shows that there is still room for improvement for transfer of numpy arrays.   It should be going through a direct memory buffer transfer, but it may be that calling a conversion function each time is slowing things down.   

Recommendation:
- [x] Identify what precise path numpy arrays are taking in the code.
- [x] Analyze the source of the slowdown.
- [ ] If it is the converter functions, then add a start1, start2, len parameter to converters so they can be used to do bulk transfer rather than just one off transfers.

items.title: TypeError when importing JPype in Python 3.8.4
items.body:
With the latest bug-fix release for Python, version 3.8.4 published two days ago, I get the following error when importing JPype on Window 10:

```pycon
$ python
Python 3.8.4 (tags/v3.8.4:dfa645a, Jul 13 2020, 16:46:45) [MSC v.1924 64 bit (AMD64)] on win32
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import jpype
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "D:\temp\Py384\Python\lib\site-packages\jpype\__init__.py", line 20, in <module>
    from ._core import *
  File "D:\temp\Py384\Python\lib\site-packages\jpype\_core.py", line 20, in <module>
    from . import types as _jtypes
  File "D:\temp\Py384\Python\lib\site-packages\jpype\types.py", line 38, in <module>
    from ._jarray import *
  File "D:\temp\Py384\Python\lib\site-packages\jpype\_jarray.py", line 213, in <module>
    _jcustomizer._applyCustomizerPost(_jpype._JArray, _JArrayProto)
  File "D:\temp\Py384\Python\lib\site-packages\jpype\_jcustomizer.py", line 166, in _applyCustomizerPost
    _applyCustomizerImpl(cls.__dict__, proto, sticky,
  File "D:\temp\Py384\Python\lib\site-packages\jpype\_jcustomizer.py", line 148, in _applyCustomizerImpl
    setter(p, v)
  File "D:\temp\Py384\Python\lib\site-packages\jpype\_jcustomizer.py", line 167, in <lambda>
    lambda p, v: type.__setattr__(cls, p, v))
TypeError: can't apply this __setattr__ to _jpype._JClass object
```

This occurs with JPype 0.7.5, the release currently available on PyPI, as well as the latest release 1.0.0, installed directly from the wheel as provided here on GitHub.

No such error occurs on the same machine with Python 3.8.3, on an equally clean install (no other packages) of JPype 0.7.5 or 1.0.0. Same for Python 3.7.8, tested on two other machines running Windows 7. So this seems to be specific to Python 3.8.4 and, possibly, Windows.

Is this error reproducible?

items.title: Import from Java package that has no subdirectories causes import error

labels.name: question
labels.description: Question on how to use JPype

items.body:
Hello,
I'm using Jpype to call methods from a Java library (.jar). The library has of course packages in it, but one type is causing me import problems. 

There are some packages with the following structure:

- com
  - sun
    -Util.class

(inside the **com** directory there is the **sun** directory which contains the **Util.class**). In this case I can successfully import the class (from python)  by using

`from com.sun import Util`

But in case I have the following structure 
- com.google
  - SoftwareUtility.class

( so there is a **SINGLE** package named **com.google** that contains the class; the google subdirectory doesn't exist) I get an import error if I do

`from com.google import SoftwareUtility`

`ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'com'`

How can I solve this?
Thanks

items.title: Directories with .class files not recognized as classpath entries

labels.name: question
labels.description: Question on how to use JPype

items.body:
Hello,

It looks like jpype can only handle .jar files as classpath entries, but not directories containing package folders and .class files, even though the documentation mentions the standard "classes" directory as possible classpath entry, see here:

https://jpype.readthedocs.io/en/latest/userguide.html#controlling-the-jvm

```python
import jpype
jpype.startJVM("-ea", classpath=['lib/*', 'classes'], convertStrings=False)
```

Would be great if that worked because that would decrease the turnaround time by not having to build .jar files but access the compiled .class files directly.

items.title: State of the project

labels.name: notice
labels.description: Long standing JPype limitation (outside of our control)

milestone.title: JPype 1.0.0
milestone.description: Complete remaining nice to have items for JPype.

items.body:
We are closing out the work for the targeted JPype 0.8 release.   Still a lot of lose ends in terms of bugs, coverage, and hardening, but I believe we are at the point where a feature freeze is warranted.

There are some questions for the release:
1) What should this be called?  One user wants us to adopt this as an actual major number making this 1.0. 
2)  How do we get enough users to test this to make a solid and stable release point?
3) What is not here that is required for a release? 
4) Does the dbapi2 interface go in this release or wait for more testing and user input?

This project is actually approaching a production level code so making it a major release with 1.0 makes sense.  I have some reservations as we still have some regrettable public interfaces that have yet to be removed.  I would like the 1.0 to be a clean point where everything in the API has been reviewed and deemed necessary (or broken and thus removed).   We are not yet at that point as there are many external symbols that are legacy which may change from nuisance (ignorable) to in the way (must remove) once I work on the reverse bridge.

Unless something is flat out broken we often don't get reports of problems with a release until months after.  But this is supposed to be a good point to last us for at least a year while I work under the hood to provide some new capabilities.  We need people to help out to make really kick the tires on this one so that we don't end up with 4 months of fixing issue and patch releases as I am gutting the places needed for the reverse bridge.   Github doesn't have a spam the users of a project (likely a good thing), but it does leave us in this type of situation.  If we do have a poor quality release and I have already started the next development cycle, then the whole repo is going to end up forked with a release branch and devel branch.   We tried that with 0.7 but I could only hold it for  months before I had to start pushing thing from devel back to release so that I wasn't constantly needing to task switch (damn didn't I fix this already, wait this assumption is different, no not this one again!)

I have laid out the road map of missing features that we are going for likely requiring 2 major versions of upgrades.
- Deprecate and remove the remaining dangerous or confusing interfaces.  Move all remaining external behaviors to the necessary factory classes (JClass and JArray) and the rest will be customizers for Java classes.  Push those that are utility like to operators like ``@`` and ``[]`` so that we look more Java like.
- Implement Python extensions of Java classes.
- Implement a reverse bridge allowing Java to call Python.
- Implement a slave JVM mode allowing a second JVM to be controlled using rmi or similar.
- Deal with the memory issues that these features will cause.

It is still a pretty long road but the end is visible on the horizon and I have a good idea how to finish all of these tasks.  It is simply a matter of coding time.

If anyone has a strong opinion on these topics please weigh in.  Otherwise we autopilot to the next point.

items.title: Reference leak in casting operator

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Unable to deliver desired behavior (crash, fail, untested)

items.body: While tracing an unexplained exception, I identified an instance in which an object inappropriately called ``keep()`` on a frame allowing the object to leak into the global scope.   To prevent this from happening the JPJavaFrames need to be segregated into three types.  External frame which are born in Java, outer frames that are not allowed to leak any resources, and inner frames which are used to control resources within outer and external frames.   This should prevent further leaks of this type as all  Java actions must be done in a frame and if those frames have rules that prevent leaking it should not be possible to leak a resource.

items.title: automatic conversion of python lists in parameters does not work until java.util.Collection(?) is imported
items.body:
Assume the following Java class:
```java
package jptest;
import java.util.Collection;

public class Test {
    public static void testMethod(Collection<String> input) {
        System.out.println(input);
    }
}
```
invoked by the following python code:
```python
import jpype

jpype.startJVM(
    jpype.getDefaultJVMPath(),
    classpath='/path/to/built/class,
    convertStrings=True
)

import jpype.imports
jpype.imports.registerDomain("jptest")

# from java.util import Collection

from jptest import Test

Test.testMethod(["a", "b"])
```

Expected result:
```
[a, b]
```

Actual result:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "D:/jpype-playground/test.py", line 16, in <module>
    Test.testMethod(["a", "b"])
TypeError: No matching overloads found for jptest.Test.testMethod(list), options are:
	public static void jptest.Test.testMethod(java.util.Collection)
```

Once `java.util.Collection`, `java.util.ArrayList` (or probably any other collection?) is imported, e.g. in the commented-out line, conversion works as expected.

JPype 0.7.3, Java 1.8 (x64) on Windows 10.

labels.description: Unable to deliver desired behavior (crash, fail, untested)

items.body:
We've been happily using JPype on Ubuntu 18.04 for a while (for which many thanks!), across variety of versions including most recently 0.7.1 and 0.7.2. We recently tried to deploy our software with 0.7.3 and found some confusing test failures with few external signs of what might be wrong:

- At least one instance of a process dying with a SIGABRT.
- We have a script we use to start and stop our code via systemd. The start/stop commands normally complete in 15-20 seconds. After a failure, the "stop" takes MUCH longer to run - perhaps one minute.
- Nothing obvious in "top" or /var/log/syslog or our system-specific logs.

We realise the above points are not very specific, but we were able to confirm by flipping between 0.7.2 and 0.7.3 that the latter is the problem.

Apologies for the rather scant report, please advise if there is some debugging steps we can assist with.

Thanks, Shaheed

P.S. We can pin to 0.7.2 as a workaround. We note that 0.7.4 has been released but we have not tried  it as it has not made its way to PyPi yet. Also, it seems to features some memory-related fixes for arrays, but we are not using arrays.

items.title: API breakage for reverse bridge
items.body:
Working through issues needed for reverse bridge (Java calling Python),  I found that the most likely source of issues is implicit casting in JPObjectType.   

In particular  Python ``int`` and ``float`` cast to ``java.lang.Long`` and ``java.lang.Double``.  But this will not be possible to guarantee in the future.  Instead these should both map to the abstract base class ``java.lang.Number`` which we can safely implement with a proper wrapper in the future.  The relative impact of this is low, but may break codes that assume a specific type.

items.title: Thread freeze on destroy

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Unable to deliver desired behavior (crash, fail, untested)

items.body:
Current we do not allow any Destroy hooks to run in Java because we are not terminating the JVM properly.  Investigating the issue, it turns out that Python threads that were attached to Java stop being serviced when the JVM DestroyJavaVM is called.  This creates a deadlock issue as the attached threads are unable to be serviced but shutdown will not proceed until all threads are terminated.   

This is one of the remaining long standing issues as we can't properly handle a shutdown other than manual termination.

items.title: how to monitor the time of function running? if overtime then exit.
items.body:
how to monitor the time of function running? if overtime then exit.

 SmilesParser is JAVA class

code as the following:
```py
smilesParser = SmilesParser(DefaultChemObjectBuilder.getInstance())



 
# coding:utf8
import time
import signal

class TimeoutError(Exception):
    def __init__(self, msg):
        super(TimeoutError, self).__init__()
        self.msg = msg
 
 
def time_out(interval, callback):
    def decorator(func):
        def handler(signum, frame):
            raise TimeoutError("run func timeout")
 
        def wrapper(*args, **kwargs):
            try:
                signal.signal(signal.SIGALRM,handler)
                signal.alarm(interval)       # interval秒后向进程发送SIGALRM信号
                result = func(*args, **kwargs)
                signal.alarm(0)              # 函数在规定时间执行完后关闭alarm闹钟
                return result
            except TimeoutError as e:
                callback(e)
        return wrapper
    return decorator
 
def timeout_callback(e):
    print(e.msg)
    return "time out"


@time_out(5, timeout_callback)
def addmapbyRDT(rxnsmi):
```

items.title: Relative paths for add path
items.body:
Java and Python have very different notions of paths.  This can lead to strange issues in two cases:

1) Relative paths that don't match the current notion of Python.  For example a jar file in a Python module where the module is referencing relative to the Python directory and Java is referencing the starting directory.
2) Operating systems for which the JVM path system does not match the python one (Cygwin).

The safest course is to use Python path lib to convert relative paths into absolute paths.  We can do this for many systems automatically.  But this has difficulties for Cygwin where its path structure differs from Java and to a lesser extent WSL. 

The user can work around the issue by manually converting the path to an absolution one but we may be able to improve this.

items.title: JImplements requires JVM to be running
items.body:
The JImplements interface is really nice - it gives overrides checking and automatic proxying for a much more pleasant interface when dealing with nested objects than the equivalent ``JProxy`` approach.

Unfortunately the ``jpype.JImplements`` currently requires the JVM to be running which can be awkward to guarantee at module definition time. I'd rather not nest my class definitions to allow me to guarantee that the JVM has been started, instead I'd like to defer the work that is done in ``JImplements`` until I try to construct an instance of my class.

I hacked together an approach using the existing public API tools to do precisely this:

```
import jpype as jp


def JImplementsDeferred(*jimplements_args, **jimplements_kwargs):
    def JProxyCreator(cls):
        # Store the __new__ method, we are going to override it for the first
        # construction of one of these cls instances. After that, we can use
        # the original class's __new__ method.
        cls.__unwrapped_new__ = cls.__new__

        def __fast_new__(cls, *args, **kwargs):
            self = cls.__unwrapped_new__(cls)
            self.__init__(*args, **kwargs)
            return self

        def __new__(cls, *args, **kwargs):
            # JImplements modifies the class's __init__ in-place.
            if getattr(cls, '__jimplements_called__', None) is None:
                jp.JImplements(*jimplements_args, **jimplements_kwargs)(cls)
                cls.__jimplements_called__ = True
            # Now put the old __new__ constructor back on this class (as
            # this doesn't need to be called again).
            cls.__new__ = cls.__fast_new__
            return cls.__new__(cls, *args, **kwargs)

        cls.__fast_new__ = __fast_new__
        cls.__new__ = __new__
        return cls
    return JProxyCreator
```

I can then use ``JImplementsDeferred`` in exactly the same way as ``jpype.JImplements`` (i.e. as a class decorator).

It basically hijacks the object constructor to do the ``jp.JImplements`` magic (which is mostly override checking and attaching a ``__javaproxy__`` attribute). After doing this once it then reverts back to using the originally defined object constructor, so there is no subsequent performance penalty. I was tempted to re-implement the ``__javaproxy__`` logic from the JImplements wrapper, but actually calling the JImplements decorator itself turned out to be fairly clean and is making use of the public JPype API.

Are there any obvious flaws to this approach? Is this something you'd like to see in jpype?

items.title: crash Python3 when adding more than a day ChronoUnit
items.body:
When defining a time with java.time.Instant, using .plus() with units ChronoUnit.WEEKS or longer kills the Python kernel.

```{python3}
# After these lines:
import jpype
import jpype.imports
jpype.startJVM(jpype.getDefaultJVMPath(), convertStrings=False)
from java.time import Instant
from java.time.temporal import ChronoUnit
start = Instant.parse("1970-01-01T00:00:00Z")

# Any of the following will fail:
print(start.plus(1, ChronoUnit.WEEKS))
print(start.plus(1, ChronoUnit.MONTHS))
print(start.plus(1, ChronoUnit.YEARS))
print(start.plus(1, ChronoUnit.DECADES))
print(start.plus(1, ChronoUnit.CENTURIES))
print(start.plus(1, ChronoUnit.MILLENNIA))
print(start.plus(1, ChronoUnit.ERAS))
print(start.plus(1, ChronoUnit.FOREVER))
```

items.title: Python references passed to the Java side for callbacks
items.body:
I have been using py4j and I build a custom reference system that allows Python objects to be returned to the Java side, and then passed back to Python.  Basically any Python object is wrapped which creates a UUID and adds it to a reference dict, and the Java side then holds this reference in a generic class (so that it is self-documenting about what it holds), and it can pass the reference back which is unwrapped into the original object.  By implementing `Closeable` on the Java side a resource try/finally block can protect that it is not leaking.

How would I do something similar in jpype?  Do I need to build the same model for it, or does it handle references already?  I see no mention of it so far in the docs.

items.title: Segfault/fatal RuntimeError with 0.7.2 and numpy
items.body:
After CI for our project [iiasa/ixmp](https://github.com/iiasa/ixmp) started building against JPype1 version 0.7.2, both via PyPI and Anaconda, we encountered frequent segfaults. These seem to occur when numpy code (via pandas) is dealing with exceptions raised from JPype, and produce messages like:
```
<M>unknown : Fatal error in exception handling</M>
<M>unknown : Handling: java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException
</M>
<M>unknown : Type: 0</M>
<M>unknown : Inner Python: java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException</M>
<M>unknown : native/python/jp_pythontypes.cpp JPPyObject 29</M>
<M>unknown : Fatal error in exception handling</M>
<M>unknown : Handling: java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException
</M>
<M>unknown : Type: 0</M>
<M>unknown : Inner Python: RuntimeError</M>
<M>unknown : native/python/jp_pythontypes.cpp JPPyObject 29</M>
<M>unknown : Fatal error in exception handling</M>
<M>unknown : Handling: java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException
</M>
<M>unknown : Type: 0</M>
<M>unknown : Inner Python: RuntimeError</M>
<M>unknown : native/python/jp_pythontypes.cpp JPPyObject 29</M>
<M>unknown : Fatal error in exception handling</M>
<M>unknown : Handling: java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException
</M>
<M>unknown : Type: 0</M>
<M>unknown : Inner Python: java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException</M>
<M>unknown : native/python/jp_pythontypes.cpp JPPyObject 29</M>
```

A full log is attached: [pytest.log](https://github.com/jpype-project/jpype/files/4344306/pytest.log)

This is a regression, because the exceptions seemed to have been successfully caught/handled in numpy, pandas, or our code with JPype1 version 0.7.1 and earlier. (our mitigation is to pin to JPype1 version 0.7.1 for CI.) Now, they are fatal and the tests fail.

Unfortunately the Java code underlying our Python is in a private repo. I'm happy to copy snippets if needed or run anything to help debug. However, from lines like the following in the tracebacks, perhaps it will be possible for you to reproduce the problem without that.
```
        try:
>           return a.ndim
E           AttributeError: 'java.lang.String[]' object has no attribute 'ndim'
```
…i.e. maybe create a java.lang.String and then try to get a non-existent attribute in Python.

The atexit solution works for well behaved code (and prevents a crash if there is something waiting in the reference queue.)  But it added one weird error at exit time if there is an active exception on the stack at the end of the program.

```
Exception ignored in tp_clear of: <class 'list'>
RuntimeError: Java Virtual Machine is not running
```

Likely this is a problem with dead resources being clear.  I will need to isolate the problem so that it can be addressed.

items.title: C++ Exceptions optional
items.body: Although C++ exceptions are very useful for tracing the source of an error in C++ code, it is likely going to be a distraction for the user.   Perhaps we should have a switch to enable this feature as it is mostly for debugging.

items.title: Segfault on waiting for GIL
items.body: If a GC cycle is started before then end of execution of Python, the reference queue can abort while waiting for the GIL lock to be returned.  There is no obvious workaround at this time other than ignoring the fault.  For some reason this is triggering some kind of exception but I can't figure out its type as of yet.

items.title: Conda-forge is serving the wrong version of JPype1
items.body:
One of my coworkers tried to pull JPype1 using conda-forge and was getting very strange behavior when using OSX.

If he specified one of the channels explicitly and used upgrade he got 0.6.3.  If he did another channel he got 0.7 install.  If he tried to force 0.7.2 it appears to have hung for a very long time.  (Perhaps it was building from source.)

I think the missing digit on the version number for 0.7.0 is haunting us as it seemed to always prefer ``osx-64/jpype1-0.7-py36hbf1eeb5_0.tar.bz2`` over ``osx-64/jpype1-0.7.2-py38ha1b3eb9_0.tar.bz2`` .  Perhaps it is having problem matching '.' against '-'.  Or there is some other problem upstream.  None of the options appears to pull the current version in his testing.   Talking through the office another user with OSX detected the same thing.

@marscher any chance you can look into this one?   I am not sure how to even start with this type of issue.

items.title: Explicit casts should not trigger OverflowError
items.body: We should limit the OverflowError to calls in which the automatic conversion is applied.  Direct casting should bypass the check so that it acts just like Java where explicit casts are performed.

items.title: 0.7.x upgrade and threading question
items.body:
We are using jpype via JayDeBeApi to access OsiSoft PI over JDBC.
So far it worked if used from single-threaded context.

From what I could gather from the jpype project page and stackoverflow etc. it should be OK to use
jpype in multi-threaded context with the appropriate thread types and if the following is done:
1) Ensure JVM is started once (assume prior to thread creation otherwise JVM start check has to be protected by a lock).
2) Ensure thread is attached to JVM prior to opening connection etc.

Examples of the above (not sure about the correctness of all of them) can be found here:
https://www.programcreek.com/python/example/107852/jpype.startJVM

Q1: Assuming conditions 1) and 2) are met, it should be OK for each thread to create its own jpype connection instance, correct?

Q2: I sometimes run into the following error when opening a jpype 0.6.3 connection from a thread:

```
# A fatal error has been detected by the Java Runtime Environment:
#
#  SIGSEGV (0xb) at pc=0x00007f7300736aeb, pid=19803, tid=19827
#
# JRE version: OpenJDK Runtime Environment (14.0+18) (build 14-ea+18-Ubuntu-1)
# Java VM: OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM (14-ea+18-Ubuntu-1, mixed mode, sharing, tiered, compressed oops, g1 gc, linux-amd64)
# Problematic frame:
# C  [_jpype.cpython-36m-x86_64-linux-gnu.so+0x46aeb]  JPMethodOverload::ensureTypeCache() const+0x1b
```

What is the typical cause of this error?

Q3: So, I tried upgrading to 0.7.2 to see if the error goes away, but then run into the following error when opening a connection:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "$HOME/.pyenv/versions/3.6.10/lib/python3.6/threading.py", line 916, in _bootstrap_inner
    self.run()
  File "$HOME/.pyenv/versions/3.6.10/lib/python3.6/threading.py", line 864, in run
    self._target(*self._args, **self._kwargs)
  File "pi_importer.py", line 161, in import_data_worker
    conn = jaydebeapi.connect("com.osisoft.jdbc.Driver", jdbc_conn, [jdbc_user, jdbc_pass], "PIJDBCDriver.jar")
  File "$HOME/.pyenv/versions/3.6.10/envs/stan/lib/python3.6/site-packages/jaydebeapi/__init__.py", line 381, in connect
    jconn = _jdbc_connect(jclassname, url, driver_args, jars, libs)
  File "$HOME/.pyenv/versions/3.6.10/envs/stan/lib/python3.6/site-packages/jaydebeapi/__init__.py", line 182, in _jdbc_connect_jpype
    for i in types.__javaclass__.getClassFields():
AttributeError: type object 'java.sql.Types' has no attribute '__javaclass__'
```

Any idea what causes this?  Bad configuration or use of jpype connection instance? Issue with the 3rd-party JDBC driver?

jpype.startJVM calls used (taken from one of the examples at previously mentioned URL):
```python
if jpype_version.startswith("0.6"):
    logging.debug("using jpype <= 0.6.x compatible JVM start")
    jpype.startJVM(jvm_path, args)
else:
    logging.debug("using jpype >= 0.7.x compatible JVM start")
    jpype.startJVM(jvm_path, args, ignoreUnrecognized=True, convertStrings=True)
```

Environment/platform details:
- Thread type: ```threading.Thread```
- OS: Ubuntu 19.10
- Python: 3.6.10
- JVM/JDK: openjdk 14-ea 2020-03-17

items.title: HashMap node does not unpack when used as iterator

labels.name: enhancement

items.body:
We need a customizer on HashMap.Node to allow for unpacking when iterating elements.

Here is an example
```
import jpype
jpype.startJVM()
java = jpype.java
hm = java.util.HashMap()
hm['alice'] = 'pickles'
hm['betty'] = 'ice cream'
hm['catty'] = 'corn'
for p,v in hm.entrySet():
    print(p, v)
```

Gives 
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "testMap2.py", line 8, in <module>
    for p,v in hm.entrySet():
TypeError: cannot unpack non-iterable java.util.HashMap.Node object
```

items.title: Support for weak references on Proxies

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Improvement in capability planned for future release

items.body:
Proxies currently cause Python objects to assume the lifespan of the Java object used to reference it.  Unfortunately there are cases in which this leads to memory exhaustion as the Java garbage collection does not trigger when Python consumes too much memory due to stale objects.  

We need a way to discover if Python memory is growing excessively and deal with it.

See test pull request #581

items.title: java.util.HashMap does not throw KeyError on bad item

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Unable to deliver desired behavior (crash, fail, untested)

items.body:
The wrapper for HashMap does not produce the expected output on a bad item like Python.

```
hm = jpype.java.util.HashMap()
try:
    print(hm["foo"])
    print("fail")
except KeyError:
    print("success")
```

We should add a check for containsKey() if the map returned None so we can throw properly.  The user can call `get` if they want Java behavior.

items.title: java.util.List getitem throws a Java exception

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Unable to deliver desired behavior (crash, fail, untested)

items.body:
The following code fails

```
jlist=java.util.List()
jlist.addAll([1,2,3,4])
try:
   jlist[6]
except IndexError:
   print("success")
```

The wrapper returns java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException which is unexpected for a Python operation.  We can fix this by making IndexOutOfBoundsException derive from IndexError internally.

items.title: java.util.Container del does not work

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Unable to deliver desired behavior (crash, fail, untested)

items.body:
`__delitem__` is tied to remove but those mean very different things.

```
jcollection = JObject(java.lang.ArrayList([11,12,13,14], java.lang.Collection)
del jcollection[13]
print(jcollection)
```

gives `[11,12,14]` because we remove item 13 not the non-existant item 13.

I will remove the bad binding as this is not likely what is intended.

items.title: convertToDirectByteBuffer leaks
items.body:
The implementation of convert to direct byte buffer is incorrect.  It creates a view of the Python memory but never releases it.  It appears to be a misunderstanding of the way that byte buffers work (likely from long ago). 

To fix this problem, Java needs to call release buffer when complete rather than unreferencing the memoryview which it does now.  Additional support on the Java side may be required.

items.title: numpy no longer optional
items.body:
In recent builds of my project I noticed that another wheel is pulled off pypi.
It used to be JPype1-0.7.1-cp37-cp37m-linux_x86_64.whl but starting this year it is JPype1-0.7.1-cp37-cp37m-manylinux1_x86_64.whl (note: version is still 0.7.1).

i used not to install the numpy extra and went fine with it. The new wheel doesn't run without numpy anymore, even though I still don't install the extra, and my build started failing.

When I require the numpy extra my build starts working again.

I would propose to either no longer use numpy at all (as suggested in another issue) or make it optional again.

items.title: Bytes conversion
items.body:
This issue has come up twice in the past month where someone wanted to convert a Java byte[] to a corresponding native Python bytes type.  The current method is to call `[:]` which is not very intuitive and a side effect of the slice implementation rather than good practice.  Worse others have tried to use `toString` which is completely different functionality wise.     

I recommend that we add the appropriate conversion customizers to JPype to make this a bit more intuitive.  We should add the customizer to the library, add a test for the customizer, and last add it to the documentation.

See #565 and 
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/59608488/python-jpype-get-value-from-instance-of-java-class/59773940#59773940

items.title: Consider removing numpy
items.body:
One of the big hang ups is currently numpy.  Our actual use of numpy is just as an interface that supports memoryview byte transfers and slicing.  There is no reason we cant just provide an array slice object with the appropriate apis implemented and drop numpy entirely.  We can still get high levels of integration by implementing `__array_interface__` without actually using numpy binarary functions. 

Related to #133, #563

items.title: Minimum Numpy versions for latest JPYPE version is no longer numpy>=1.6
items.body:
By using versions between 1.6 and 1.15.4, importing jpype will results in the following error: 

```
>>> import jpype
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'numpy.core._multiarray_umath'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/jpype/__init__.py", line 17, in <module>
    import _jpype
ImportError: numpy.core.multiarray failed to import
```

Updating the minimal requirements to numpy>=1.16.0 will solve the issue.

See https://github.com/jpype-project/jpype/blob/afe8a8bc002959ba0a727795d6be68fbd6aabefc/setup.py#L41

items.title: “Windows fatal exception: access violation” on Windows using pytest
items.body:
At iiasa/ixmp#229 and iiasa/ixmp#247 we are trying to deal with noisy console messages from JPype that show up on Windows when running our pytest suite. See iiasa/ixmp#229 for lots of detail; the short version is that they look like:
```
Windows fatal exception: access violation

Current thread 0x00000864 (most recent call first):
  File "C:\Miniconda36-x64\lib\site-packages\jpype\_core.py", line 227 in startJVM
  File "C:\projects\ixmp\tests\backend\test_jdbc.py", line 18 in test_gh_229
  File "C:\Miniconda36-x64\lib\site-packages\_pytest\python.py", line 166 in pytest_pyfunc_call
  File "C:\Miniconda36-x64\lib\site-packages\pluggy\callers.py", line 187 in _multicall
  File "C:\Miniconda36-x64\lib\site-packages\pluggy\manager.py", line 81 in <lambda>
```
To be clear, our *Java code and JPype function correctly* and our test suite succeeds; the issue is that many (many…) lines of such messages clutter the pytest output, making it impossible to read.

The messages are triggered by many entry points in our Java code, but I have tried to isolate a simplest-possible case in iiasa/ixmp#247 and (in vain) to identify the cause. Details follow.

1. As of the latest commit, the AppVeyor install script looks like this: https://github.com/iiasa/ixmp/blob/1079c8e08ec47e01819bfe0c05b430ff20a82aa4/.appveyor.yml#L27-L31
   …i.e. JPype1 `master` is installed by building the source directly from GitHub. Then the script [ci/appveyor-gh_229.py](https://github.com/iiasa/ixmp/blob/1079c8e08ec47e01819bfe0c05b430ff20a82aa4/ci/appveyor-gh_229.py) is run.
2. The build log is [here](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/iiasa/ixmp/builds/30049134/job/9r0ao6yt88gwvsmy); the output from the script is at [lines 739–754](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/iiasa/ixmp/builds/30049134/job/9r0ao6yt88gwvsmy#L739). Note that the “Windows fatal exception” message **does not** appear.
3. Then, the AppVeyor test script runs just one test, a new one that I have added to our pytest suite for debugging this issue: https://github.com/iiasa/ixmp/blob/1079c8e08ec47e01819bfe0c05b430ff20a82aa4/.appveyor.yml#L39-L41
   This test function is identical to appveyor-gh_229.py: https://github.com/iiasa/ixmp/blob/1079c8e08ec47e01819bfe0c05b430ff20a82aa4/tests/backend/test_jdbc.py#L10-L20
4. The output of this pytest invocation is at [lines 972–1063](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/iiasa/ixmp/builds/30049134/job/9r0ao6yt88gwvsmy#L972) of the same build log. Note that there is no exception of any sort raised; the test passes. But see lines 981–1020 for the “Windows fatal exception” message. When running the full test suite, there are dozens of similar, ~30-line messages.

At this point, I am stumped; I do not know why the messages appear in step 3/4 but not in 1/2; nor can I find any information about how to further debug this issue.

cc @zikolach
